fr:title.text: Equational theory of cartesian closed categories

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Equational theory of cartesian closed categories

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: In addition to those of a cartesian category, a cartesian closed category C saitsfies the following equations up to natural isomorphism:

To see the first, note that C(-, 1^x)\cong C(-\times x, 1)\cong *, and the Yoneda embedding reflects limits, so that 1^x is terminal in C. for a more abstract proof, observe that (-)^x has a right adjoint, so preserves limits.
To see the second, note that C(-, x^1)\cong C(-\times 1, x)\cong C(-, x), and representable isomorphism is isomorphism.

To see the third, note that \begin {aligned} C(-, (y\times z)^x) &\cong C(-\times x, y\times z) \\ &\cong C(-\times x, y)\times C(-\times x, z) \\ &\cong C(-, y^x)\times C(-, z^x) \\ &\cong C(-, y^x\times z^x). \end {aligned} In particular, the second step uses the representability of limits.

To see the fourth, note that \begin {aligned} C(-, x^{y\times z}) &\cong C(-, x^{z\times y}) \\ &\cong C(-\times (z\times y), x) \\ &\cong C((-\times z)\times y, x) \\ &\cong C(-\times z, x^y) \\ &\cong C(-, (x^y)^z). \end {aligned}

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Sheaves in geometry and logic
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: @book{maclane-moerdijk-1994, title = {Sheaves in Geometry and Logic: A First Introduction to Topos Theory}, author = {MacLane, S. and Moerdijk, I.}, isbn = {9781461209270}, doi = {10.1007/978-1-4612-0927-0} lccn = {91033709}, series = {Universitext}, url = {https://books.google.com/books?id=LZWLBAAAQBAJ}, year = {1994}, publisher = {Springer New York}, }

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: We dedicate this book to the memory of J. Frank Adams. His clear insights have inspired many mathematicians, including both of us. In January 1989, when the first draft of our book had been completed, we heard the sad news of his untimely death. This has cast a shadow on our subsequent work. Our views of topos theory, as presented here, have been shaped by continued study, by conferences, and by many personal contacts with friends and colleagues-including especially O. Bruno, P. Freyd, J.M.E. Hyland, P.T. Johnstone, A. Joyal, A. Kock, F.W. Lawvere, G.E. Reyes, R Solovay, R Swan, RW. Thomason, M. Tierney, and G.C. Wraith. Our presentation combines ideas and results from these people and from many others, but we have not endeavored to specify the various original sources. Moreover, a number of people have assisted in our work by pro viding helpful comments on portions of the manuscript. In this respect, we extend our hearty thanks in particular to P. Corazza, K. Edwards, J. Greenlees, G. Janelidze, G. Lewis, and S. Schanuel.

fr:title.text: Equational theory of bicartesian closed categories

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Equational theory of bicartesian closed categories

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: In addition to those of a cartesian closed category and the duals to those of a cartesian category, a bicartesian closed category C saitsfies the following equations up to natural isomorphism:

fr:ul.fr:li: x\times (y+z)\cong x\times y + x\times z (and in particular, C is a distributive category);

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: To show the first, note that \times is a left adjoint and left adjoints preserve colimits.

To show the second, note that \begin {aligned} C(-, x^{y+z}) &\cong C(-\times (y+z), x) \\ &\cong C(y+z, x^-) \\ &\cong C(y, x^-)\times C(z, x^-) \\ &\cong C(-\times y, x)\times C(-\times z, x) \\ &\cong C(-, x^{y})\times C(-, x^{z}) \\ &\cong C(-, x^y\times x^z). \end {aligned} In particular, the third line uses the representability of colimits, while the last uses that of limits. Now the result follows by the Yoneda lemma.

To see the third, we can again argue by left adjoint preserve colimits. More directly, we argue from initiality of 0 that C(x\times 0, -) \cong C(0, -^x) \cong *. Now we obtain the result by applying the fact that the the Yoneda reflects limits in C^\text {op}.
To see the fourth, note that C(-, x^0) \cong C(-\times 0, x) \cong C(0, x)\cong *.
A cartesian closed category is a cartesian monoidal category whose monoidal structure is closed. In this case, we call the internal hom [x, y] an exponential object, and write it y^x.
A cartesian category C satisfies the following equations up to natural isomorphism:
By the representability of limits, each of these follows from the corresponding result in Set.

fr:title.text: Yoneda embedding preserves and reflects limits

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Yoneda embedding preserves and reflects limits

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: The Yoneda embedding preserves and reflects limits.
Preservation of limits follows because hom-functors preserve limits and limits in functor categories are computed pointwise.
Reflection of limits follows because the Yoneda embedding is fully faithful and fully faithful functors reflect limits.

Let J\xrightarrow {F} C be a diagram in a locally small category C whose limit exists. Then there is a natural isomorphism C(x, \operatorname *{lim} F)\cong \operatorname *{lim} C(x, F-), where the latter is a limit in Set.
Dually, let the colimit of F exist. Then there is a natural isomorphism C(\operatorname *{colim} F, x)\cong \operatorname *{lim}_{J^\text {op}} C(F-, x).
A functor C\xrightarrow {F} D preserves limits if for every diagram J\xrightarrow {K} C and every limit cone over K, the image of this cone under F is a limit cone over FK.
An terminal object is a limit of an empty diagram.
By the universal property of limits, an object t is terminal in the category C if and only if for every object c, there is a unique morphism c\to t.
Let x and y be objects in a category C. Then the following are equivalent:

fr:ul.fr:li: the covariant hom-functors C(x, -) and C(y, -) are naturally isomorphic;
the contravariant hom-functors C(-, x) and C(-, y) are naturally isomorphic.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Furthermore, by the Yoneda embedding, a choice of any such isomorphism canonically determines a choice of each of the others.
This is immediate from the Yoneda lemma, since fully faithful functors create isomorphism.
We prove the covariant case. The forwards result comes from functoriality of the Yoneda embedding and the fact that functors preserve isomorphism.

In the backward direction, let \eta : C(x, -)\to C(y, -) be a natural isomorphism. Define t = \eta _x(1_x), which is a morphism y\to x, and u = \eta _y^{-1}(1_y), which is a morphism x\to y. We claim these are inverses.
A natural isomorphism is an isomorphism in a functor category. Explicitly, it is a natural transformation whose components are each isomorphisms.
